statement: Understanding Recurrent Ascites. Recurrent ascites is characterized by repeated accumulation of fluid in the abdominal cavity. Symptoms may include abdominal distension, discomfort, and shortness of breath.
matched_evidence:
- 1.Chiejina M,2023.pdf: Ascites is the pathologic accumulation of fluid within the peritoneal cavity.|Patients typically report progressive abdominal distension that may be painless or associated with abdominal discomfort, weight gain, early satiety, shortness of breath, and dyspnea resulting from fluid accumulation and increased abdominal pressure.
- 2. Madhumita Premkumar,2025.pdf: Recurrent ascites refers to fluid accumulation in the abdomen that returns at least three times per year, despite dietary sodium restriction and diuretic treatment.
page_location: Page 1, Introduction | Page 2, History and Physical | Page 1, paragraph 1

statement: What Are Your Treatment Options?. Compare your options for managing recurrent ascites.
matched_evidence: - 3.Berger JM,2023.pdf: Management of patients with MA still represents a clinical challenge for physicians. |Patients are highly symptomatic and require frequent interventions, but standardized, evidence based treatment guidelines are lacking. |The following paragraphs summarize existing data on treatment options for MA.
page_location: Page 4, Treatment options for malignant ascites

statement: Large Volume Paracentesis. Large volume paracentesis (LVP) involves insertion of a needle into the peritoneal cavity to drain excess fluid and provide temporary relief from recurrent ascites.
matched_evidence:
- 3.Berger JM,2023.pdf: The most commonly used procedure to relieve symptoms of MA is a paracentesis that provides temporary symptom relieve by draining the excess fluid.
- 4.Aponte EM, 2019.pdf: Paracentesis is a fundamental bedside procedure used for diagnostic and therapeutic purposes in patients with ascites, defined as abnormal fluid accumulation within the peritoneal cavity.|The procedure involves inserting a needle into the peritoneal space to remove ascitic fluid, which may be performed for diagnostic or therapeutic purposes.
page_location: Page 7, under the section "Serial large volume paracentesis and permanent drainage" | Page 1, Introduction, Page 2, Anatomy and Physiology

statement: Large Volume Paracentesis. Outpatient procedure performed in a hospital
matched_evidence: - 5.Gilani N,2019.pdf: A retrospective analysis of patients undergoing an outpatient LVP at our institution was performed between January 2003 and May 2007.

statement: Large Volume Paracentesis. Repetitive procedure required whenever fluid builds up impairing QoL
matched_evidence: - 6.Macken L,2018.pdf: The most common palliative management for refractory ascites due to ESLD is large volume paracentesis (LVP), performed every 10–14 days [3].

statement: Large Volume Paracentesis. Up to 97 mins required per drainage
matched_evidence: - 7. Grabau 2004.pdf: The mean duration of large-volume paracentesis was 97 ± 24 minutes, and the mean volume of ascitic fluid removed was 8.7 ± 2.8 L.

statement: Diuretics. Diuretics are medications that increase excretion of sodium and water, aiming to achieve a negative sodium balance and reduce fluid accumulation in the abdominal cavity.
matched_evidence: - 8.Zaccherini G,2021.pdf: The initiation of a diuretic therapy has the goal to induce natriuresis and consequently a negative sodium balance.

statement: Diuretics. Oral administration, especially for ascites from liver cirrhosis (requires careful assessment of kidney function, risk of hypovolemia, and ototoxicity)
matched_evidence: - 9.Arumugham VB,2023.pdf: Diuretics, along with salt restriction, are also recommended as the first-line therapy in ascites due to liver cirrhosis.[13]

statement: Diuretics. Administered once or twice daily
matched_evidence:
- 10.Sica DA, 2011.pdf: All thiazide-type diuretics can be administered once daily, which for convenience sake usually occurs in the morning.
- 11.Magdy JS,2022.pdf: Furosemide (frusemide) is the most commonly used first-line therapy, which is typically started at a dose of 20-40 mg once daily in the outpatient setting.
page_location: Page 6, under the section Variations in Response and Use in Special Situations/Populations | Page 2, Principles of diuretic therapy

statement: Diuretics. Regular monitoring required for electrolyte imbalance or kidney damage
matched_evidence:
- 12.Aithal GP,2020.pdf: 4.2. All patients initiating diuretics should be monitored for adverse events.|Almost half of those with adverse events require diuretic discontinuation or dose reduction.|Monitor for diuretic adverse events. Temporarily discontinue diuretics if electrolyte imbalance (Na < 125 mmol), worsening hypokalaemia, hyperkalaemia, serum creatinine, hepatic encephalopathy and muscle cramps
- 13.Huxel C,2023.pdf: Electrolyte requires monitoring periodically to assess diuretic tolerance.|In those with advanced renal failure with symptoms of fluid overload, physicians should closely monitor fluid status and renal function to prevent the onset of oliguria, BUN, creatinine increases, and azotemia.
page_location: Page 3, section 4.2 and Page 22, section Adverse reactions to diuretics | Page 3: Monitoring section | Page 3: Monitoring section

statement: Indwelling Peritoneal Catheter. An indwelling peritoneal catheter is a long-term option for managing recurrent ascites, allowing patients to drain excess fluid at home. This supports greater independence and improved quality of life.
matched_evidence: - 14.Amalie Thogersen,2025.pdf: The use of indwelling peritoneal catheters (IPeCs) has changed the management of recurrent ascites. These devices enable continuous home-based drainage, reducing the need for repeated hospital interventions while enhancing patient autonomy and quality of life [11].|A key advantage of indwelling catheters is that they enable patients to remain in their own homes, potentially with support from home care services, rather than requiring institutionalization.

statement: Indwelling Peritoneal Catheter. One-time outpatient procedure to place catheter
matched_evidence: - 15.Tunneled Indwelling Catheters for Malignant Ascites ,2025.pdf: This is usually performed as an outpatient procedure by an Interventional Radiology clinician (2).

statement: Indwelling Peritoneal Catheter. Fewer hospitalization days improving QoL
matched_evidence: - 14.Amalie Thogersen,2025.pdf: The use of indwelling peritoneal catheters (IPeCs) has changed the management of recurrent ascites. These devices enable continuous home-based drainage, reducing the need for repeated hospital interventions while enhancing patient autonomy and quality of life [11].|Our study confirms that indwelling catheters can be safely used for both malignant and non-malignant conditions. |Our study highlights their role in minimizing the need for hospital, maintaining patient autonomy, and minimizing complications.

statement: Indwelling Peritoneal Catheter. Drainage performed at home
matched_evidence: - 14.Amalie Thogersen,2025.pdf: The use of indwelling peritoneal catheters (IPeCs) has changed the management of recurrent ascites. These devices enable continuous home-based drainage, reducing the need for repeated hospital interventions while enhancing patient autonomy and quality of life [11].

statement: Indwelling Peritoneal Catheter. Frequency of Use | Column: Repeated drainage at home as needed | Content:
matched_evidence: - 14.Amalie Thogersen,2025.pdf: The use of indwelling peritoneal catheters (IPeCs) has changed the management of recurrent ascites. | These devices enable continuous home-based drainage, reducing the need for repeated hospital interventions while enhancing patient autonomy and quality of life [11].

statement: Large Volume Paracentesis. Hospital Visits | Column: Hospital/clinic visits each time fluid builds up | Content:
matched_evidence: - 6.Macken L,2018.pdf: The most common palliative management for refractory ascites due to ESLD is large volume paracentesis (LVP), performed every 10–14 days [3]. | This involves a costly 24-48 h hospital admission, insertion of a temporary abdominal drain and removal of up to 15 L of ascitic fluid over 4-6 h.

statement: Diuretics. Hospital Visits | Column: Regular monitoring of electrolytes & kidney function | Content:
matched_evidence:
- 12.Aithal GP,2020.pdf: Diuretics can have side effects such dehydration, confusion, abnormal levels of sodium and potassium and kidney damage. Therefore patients should be monitored while taking these tablets.|4.2. All patients initiating diuretics should be monitored for adverse events.
- 13.Huxel C,2023.pdf: Electrolyte requires monitoring periodically to assess diuretic tolerance. | Clinicians should include periodic monitoring of blood pressures, fluid status (including weight), serum electrolytes, and renal function in continued diuretic treatments.
page_location: Page 6 and 3 | Page 3, Monitoring section | Page 4, Enhancing Healthcare Team Outcomes section

statement: Indwelling Peritoneal Catheter. Hospital Visits | Column: Hospital visits not required once catheter in place | Content:
matched_evidence:
- 14.Amalie Thogersen,2025.pdf: In our study, 70% of pleural catheter patients and 76% of peritoneal catheter patients had no hospital visits due to catheter-related issues.
- 15.Tunneled Indwelling Catheters for Malignant Ascites ,2025.pdf: Placement may also be considered in patients for whom disease burden makes frequent clinic visits difficult, and when post-procedural symptoms, such as discomfort, fatigue, and dizziness, are troublesome (4,5).
page_location: Page 9, Discussion section | Page 2, under the 'Indication' section

matched_evidence: - 15.Tunneled Indwelling Catheters for Malignant Ascites ,2025.pdf: Cost The event cost for an initial tunneled catheter placement varies but has been estimated around $2500 with a repeat cost of $250 per 10-day cycle (10).

matched_evidence: - 6.Macken L,2018.pdf: The most common palliative management for refractory ascites due to ESLD is large volume paracentesis (LVP), performed every 10–14 days [3]. | This involves a costly 24-48 h hospital admission, insertion of a temporary abdominal drain and removal of up to 15 L of ascitic fluid over 4-6 h.

statement: Diuretics. Invasiveness | Column: Non-invasive (oral medication) | Content:
matched_evidence: - 11.Magdy JS,2022.pdf: Although the focus should be on ensuring that patients are treated with the maximum tolerated doses of these guideline-directed therapies, diuretics continue to play a key role in the management of clinical congestion in all forms of heart failure.

statement: Indwelling Peritoneal Catheter. Invasiveness | Column: Minimally invasive insertion | Content:
matched_evidence: - 16.Peppelenbosch A,2008.pdf: The minimal invasive percutaneous insertion bears the risk of bowel perforation and catheter malpositioning, and the outcome of this technique is strongly related to the experience of the surgeon.

statement: Large Volume Paracentesis. Pain or Side Effects | Column: Hypotension, wound infection, leakage of fluid at the needle insertion site | Content:
matched_evidence:
- 6.Macken L,2018.pdf: Expected SARs will include the following (but only if they result in hospitalisation):
•	Drain leakage or blockage
page_location: Page 20, under the section 'Expected serious adverse reactions (SARS)'

statement: Diuretics. Pain or Side Effects | Column: Electrolyte imbalances, dehydration, hypotension, ototoxicity, renal dysfunction | Content:
matched_evidence: - 13.Huxel C,2023.pdf: Adverse effects for loops diuretics typically occur from electrolyte imbalances secondary to the diuresis effects, which include: hyponatremia, hypokalemia, hypochloremia, hypomagnesemia, metabolic alkalosis, prerenal azotemia, dehydration, hypertriglyceridemia, hypercholesterolemia, hyperuricemia, gout, restlessness, headache, dizziness, vertigo, postural hypotension, and syncope. | Other adverse reactions include skin photosensitivity, interstitial nephritis, tinnitus, ototoxicity, deafness, and in patients with renal failure who receive high doses, myalgias, and muscle soreness.

statement: Indwelling Peritoneal Catheter. Pain or Side Effects | Column: Infection and catheter blockage | Content:
matched_evidence: - 16.Peppelenbosch A,2008.pdf: The outflow failure may be due to multiple causes, including clots or fibrin in the catheter, kink in the subcutaneous tunnel, placement of the catheter in the omentum, development of omental wrap or adhesions in the abdomen.|Early peritonitis with catheter placement may be a sign of a poor surgical technique.

statement: Indwelling Peritoneal Catheter. Minimally invasive placement: A small tube is inserted through a tiny abdomen incision during a simple outpatient procedure.
matched_evidence:
- 16.Peppelenbosch A,2008.pdf: The minimal invasive percutaneous insertion bears the risk of bowel perforation and catheter malpositioning, and the outcome of this technique is strongly related to the experience of the surgeon.
- 17.Long term drains to treat ascites, 2024..pdf: Your doctor makes 2 small cuts in the skin of your abdomen. | They pass the drain through the top cut, and under the skin to the wire. | They then thread the drain down the wire and into your abdomen.
page_location: Page 1, Results section | Page 2, describing the procedure for placing a long term drain

statement: Indwelling Peritoneal Catheter. Simple home drainage: When fluid builds up, connect the tube to a vacuum bottle. Each session takes 5-15 minutes.
matched_evidence: - 17.Long term drains to treat ascites, 2024..pdf: One end of the drain is in your abdomen. The other end is outside your body. When the fluid from your abdomen needs removing, you or your nurse connects a bottle to the end of the drain outside your body. The bottle has a vacuum that pulls the fluid into it.|It usually takes between 5 and 15 minutes to drain the fluid.
page_location: Page 1, What is a long term drain? | Page 4

statement: Indwelling Peritoneal Catheter. Continuous symptom control: Drain fluid at home, reducing hospital visits and improving comfort.
matched_evidence: - 14.Amalie Thogersen,2025.pdf: The use of indwelling peritoneal catheters (IPeCs) has changed the management of recurrent ascites. These devices enable continuous home-based drainage, reducing the need for repeated hospital interventions while enhancing patient autonomy and quality of life [11].|By enabling home-based fluid drainage, catheters help reduce symptom burden without requiring frequent hospital visits, supporting both patient independence and caregiver well-being while also reducing hospital expenditures [16].|Our study highlights their role in minimizing the need for hospital, maintaining patient autonomy, and minimizing complications.

statement: Indwelling Peritoneal Catheter. 100% catheter placement success
matched_evidence: - 18.Proux A, 2024.pdf: Catheter placement success was 100%.

statement: Indwelling Peritoneal Catheter. 76% had no hospital visits due to catheter-related complications.
matched_evidence: - 14.Amalie Thogersen,2025.pdf: Importantly, 70% of IPC and 76% of IPeC patients had no hospital visits due to catheter-related complications, supporting the safety and outpatient feasibility of these devices.|Frequent hospital admissions increase the risk of hospital-acquired infections. In our study, 70% of pleural catheter patients and 76% of peritoneal catheter patients had no hospital visits due to catheter-related issues.

statement: Indwelling Peritoneal Catheter. 83% to 100% of patients enjoyed relief from ascites symptoms.
matched_evidence: - 19.Courtney ,2008.pdf: At weekly follow-up, 83%-100% of subjects reported their ascites to be well controlled.

statement: Indwelling Peritoneal Catheter. Infection rate as low as 6%.
matched_evidence: - 14.Amalie Thogersen,2025.pdf: Similarly, only 6% of peritoneal catheter patients developed peritonitis.

statement: The catheter is inserted in the abdomen for draining ascites.
matched_evidence: - 20. PeritX IFU.pdf: The PeritX™™ Peritoneal Catheter System is indicated for intermittent, long term drainage of symptomatic, recurrent, malignant and non-malignant ascites that does not respond to medical management of the underlying disease and for the palliation of symptoms related to recurrent ascites.

statement: The protective dressing is virtually undetectable under clothing.
